newsitem.title: BULGARIA: Bulgaria's gypsies see no hope in election.
newsitem.headline: Bulgaria's gypsies see no hope in election.

text.p: Bulgaria's 300,000 Gypsies, destitute and despised in the land they have lived in for centuries, are the most cynical of Sunday's voters.
Overwhelmed by a sense of the futility of politics, most see the presidential run-off as a charade.
In this Gypsy ghetto on the outskirts of the capital, where many of the 3,000 inhabitants live crammed 10 to a room, the future is remorselessly bleak, whoever wins.
"Nothing is going to change here," said Kostadin Ferdinandov. "Those who manage to survive the coming winter will regret it in the spring -- all they'll have is yet more misery to look forward to."
Bulgaria's Gypsies are thought to have first come from the Punjab region of India around the 10th century.
They were nomadic until the 1960s, when the communist authorities began a campaign of forcible assimilation, severely curbing their religious and culture habits.
They were made to settle in Soviet-style collective farms, or in special housing projects like Filipovtsi.
After years of neglect, the district is now little more than a shanty-town, with many of its small houses in ruins and no paved streets or running water.
"You can feel the sense of the desperation in each house," said Marin Borisov who has lived all his 34 years there.
"I can't see any difference between the candidates," he told Reuters. "They come when there are elections, they promise the earth and then they desert us,"
Vassil Mitakov added: "I was born here, my children were born here and my grandchildren will be -- the election has no meaning for us as we are doomed to live in misery."
Most of Bulgaria's Gypsies are unemployed and say nobody wants them even for the dirtiest work.
Living in the margins of society, Gypsies have traditionally aroused deep suspicion among ordinary Bulgarians.
Scattered through all the big towns, uneducated and unemployed, many live on theft, prostitution, gambling and begging.
Two years ago, police estimated they were behind some 33 percent of crime in Bulgaria where they make up just 3.4 percent of the population.
That image has helped push the Gypsies to the bottom of the social pile in a country where resources are scarce and likely to become even more so during the coming winter.
With even relatively well-off Bulgarians facing possible food and fuel shortages in the coming months, the outlook for Filipovtsi looks grim.
"Nothing has changed during all those years here, and I doubt anything is going to happen now," said Eleonora Kadelieva, a doctor who has worked in the area for 18 years.
